coredata.dc:title: Induced rotational Raman scattering and the dipole-octopole polarizability of SF6
coredata.dc:creator: El-Sheikh, S.M.
Meinander, N.
Tabisz, G.C.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The collision-induced depolarized light scattering spectrum of SF6 is measured in the frequency range 0–100 cm−1 at pressures of 11.6 to 19 atm at 295 K. Induced rotational Raman scattering is present but the magnitude of the dipole-octopole polarizability deduced depends markedly on the intermolecular potential.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 118, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 July 1985 INDUCED ROTATIONAL RAMAN SCATTERING AND THE DIPOLE-OCTOPOLE POLARIZABILITY OF SF(, S.M. EL-SHEIKH, N. MEINANDER and G.C. TABISZ Department of Physics. University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada R3T 2N2 Received 25 April 1985 The collision-induced depolarized light scaltering spectrum of SF& is measured in the frequency range 0-100 cm"' at pressures of 11.6 lo 19 aim at 295 K- Induced rotational Rflman scailering is preseni but the magnitude of the dipolc oclopole polarizability deduced depends markedly on the inleirnolecular polenlial- L Introduction Collision-induced rotational Ran-ian transitions have been identified in the Rayleigh wing spectrum of iso- tropic molecules and a theory explaining their occur- rence in terms of long-range molecular interactions has been developed [1 5]. CH4 seems to be a partic- ularly propitous case and its spectrum has been clearly analyzed [3,6,7]. SFg was investigated by Shelton and'labisz [3] but interpretation of the scattering data was rendered ambiguous by the possible presence of impurity bands- This paper reports a new study of the depolarized Rayleigh scattering by compressed gaseous SFg at 295 K, provides much more convincing evidence for induced rotational effects and gives a finner value for the magnitude of the dipole octopole polarizability. 2. Experiment The spectroscopic apparatus has been described [3,6]. Bxcital'on was at 5145 A and observations of the scattered light were made along the direction of polarization of the incident light. To ensure detection of the weak wings where the contribution of the ro- tational spectrum is significant, spectral slit widths of 4 cm"1 were used. The SFg, supplied by Matheson (99.99% purity), was passed through small-pore filters - to remove dust. Samples at pressures from 11.6 to 19.0 0 009-2614/85/S 0330 Eisevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) atm at 295 K. were scanned in the range 10 200 cm"1- For normalization of data with respect to variations in exp rimental conditions, the integrated intensity of the v^ vibrational line at 775 cm"1 was taken as an internal intensity standard- Up to 10 scans were made at each pressure and the spectra thus averaged. Absolute intensities were determined by comparison of the intensity of the SFg profile at 9-1 atm with that of argon at 27.2 atm (see section 3) Densities were calculated from the PVT data compiled by Dymond and Smith [8]- 3. Data treatment At the densities studied,the intensity7due to in- duced scattering is expected to arise mainly, although not exclusively, from interacting pairs of molecules and be proportional to the square of the density p2. The intensity of allowed bands of SFg or impurity molecules would vary simply as p. Therefore, in the first step of the analysis, the data were fitted at a series of frequencies v in the range 10 to 110 cm"1 to an expression of the form /00=C(iOp+Z O/)p2- Following the observation ofRosenbsrg and Birnbaum [9] of allowed vibrational difference bands at 92 and 173 cm"1 in the far-infrared spectrum ofSFg. it had been surmised that similar bands might occur in the 151 Volume 118, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19Julyl9& Ram an spectrurn as well. However the function C(v) strongly resembled the spectrum of air in the range 50 110 cm 1 and the component D(v) had negligible intensity beyond 80 cm"1. Thus the observed intensity at high frequencies -was considered exclusively due to air. Although the concentration of the impurity was estimated to be only of the order of 70 ppm, its spec- trum, lying in a region where induced rotational scat- tering is important, was troublesome and had to be subtracted numerically from the data. Accordingly Gaussian-broadened spectra ofO^ and N3 were computed using well-known relative intensity expressions [10]. The total spectral intensity and width of the broadening function were left as parameters, specified by the fit of the calculated to the measured spectrum over the range 102 1 10 cm~1 at each pressure. Then the air spectrum was subtracted over the entire observed frequency range. The widths and broadening coefficients found are consistent -with those reported from detailed study [111. The resultant cm' Fig- L Two-body spectrum of SFg. Experiment (crosses); trans- lational spectrum calculated with the corrected DID form. for P(r), eq- (2) (dashed Line); rotational spectrum calculated with E= 16.7 A5 (dotted line), total calculated spectrum (solid line). Calculations performed with the McCoubrey and Singh potential spectra were then considered due solely to collisions among SFg molecules. The intensity I(v) of these spectra -were expressed as a virial expansion in the density [12]: I(v) = /t2) ( ,) pi + J(3) (,,) p3 .. ^ where I^(v) and I^Cv) are respectively the two- ani three-body correlation spectra. These were placed on an absolute intensity scale by comparison of their in- tensities at 14.9 cm 1 with that of the 27-2 aim Ar spectrum at 18.9 cm"1 , for which three-body con- tributions were assumed negligible. The argon two- body intensity at 18.9 cm"1 was taken tobe 1.001 X 10-53 A6 [13]./CT(v) for SFe is shown in fig. I- Tiie points below 10 cm"1 were obtained by normalizing the narrow-slit data ofShelton and Tabii [3] to the present results- 4. Calculation of theoretical spectra Collision-induced Light scattering concerns the ligl scattered from two or more interacting molecules or atoms. Its principal component may be thought of-as due to a translational Raman effect, arising mainly b: the dipole induced-dipole (DID) and electron overia interactions [14]. Additional contributions from dipoles induced by field gradients form the induced rotational spectrum [ 1,2]. These depend on high-orde multipolar polarizabilities. In this section, the calcu- lation of theoretical spectra for comparison with ex- periment will be described. The purely translational and rotational components wul be generated indeper dently under the assumption of separability of trans- lational and rotational motion. 4.1. Trans at onal spectrum The first-order DID interaction gives a totally anisotropic pair polarizability [15] ( (D= 6(^-3, (J where 0:0 is the dipole polanzability of the isolated molecule sndr is the intermole cular distance. To ac- count for higher-order DID and overlap interactions, (r) has frequently been written as [16] 0-)=6 a^ r-3 +Ar-6 - B exp(-r//o), (: 152 Volume 118, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 July 1985 where A, B and/g are constants determined empiri- cally. Recently it has been realized [17] that the number of parameters in (2) may be reduced. First the DID series is cut atr~6 term while collecting its classical coefficient for dispersion effects; then [18] A = 6 a3 + 7Cg/3ao , (3) where f is the second hyperpolarizability and C, is the dispersion coefficient. Secondly, the constant 7-0 is obtained from the value calculated for the He He pair polarizability by ab initio methods [19] with the assumption that rn scales with the intermolecular sep- aration at the potential minimum; thus TQ = 0 51762 A There is then a single parameter B left unspecified in (2). Analysis of the collision-induced spectra of Ne, Ar, Kr and Xe and the translational part of the spectrum ofCH4,with-i4 andT-o fixed as described above, yielded reduced values for-B, ^^m^O' of very similar magnitude for all these systems [17]. In the present SFg calculation, a value for5* in the same range was somewhat arbitrarily chosen Lennard-Jones (28 7) potentials have been found suitable to describe the interactions of large quasi- spherical molecules [20,21], U(r) = (44/3/3)e [(a/r)28 _ (a/r)7 ] . (4) Two such potentials of long-standing in the literature are that ofHamann and Lambert [20] (a = 5.03 A and e = 414 K) and that of McCoubrey and Singh [21] (ff = 4.68 A and e = 439 K). A recent study by Powles et ai. [22] specified a potential based on pressure and structural second virial coefficients with a = 5.084 A and e = 404 K, values very close to those obtained earlier by Hamann and Lambert. Classical lineshapes were calculated following the approach described by Frommhold [23] and Bafile et al [16], using both (1) and (2) for (r) and all of these (28 7) potentials. Values of other necessary parameters were OEQ = 4.549 A3 [24], y= 12 C4 m4 J-3 [25], and B = 2800 A3. Cg was estimated from potential data to be 870 au. The spectral moments M., of these computed classi- cal profiles were significantly smaller than those cal- culated from explicit analytical expressions for the moments [26 28]. These differences are presumed to arise from the fact that the moment expressions include the contribution of dimers to the spectrum, while in the classical lineshape calculation only tra- jectories of unbound pairs are considered. For systems for which contributions to the spectrum from bound dimers are insignificant, such as neon at room tempera- ture or argon at high temperature (2600 K), excellent agreement between the theoretical moments, calculated from the analytical expressions for the moments [26 28]. and the moments of the computed classical profiles has consistently been obtained, verifying that the con- tribution to the spectrum of the unbound states is calcu- lated correctly, within the classical framework, by the computer code.With the Powles potential the dirner con- tributions to the moments are 42% (My), 22% ( f;), 19% (M^) and 6% (Mg). Using this estimate of the moments, the dimer band profile was modelled as the sum of a Gaussian and an exponential [29], a reasonable approximation to the shape observed for the CH4 CH4 dimer spectrum by Prengel and Gornall [30]. An example of the total calculated translational profile is shown in fig. 1. The profile falls off much more rapidly at high frequency when (2) is used for (r) rather than simply the first-order DID expression. 4.2 Induced rotational spectrum In the theory of Buckingham and Tabisz [1,2] the induction of pair dipole moments, which lead to the pair polarizability contributions which rotate with the interacting molecules, is described through multi- pole polarizabuities of order higher than the dipole polarizability. For molecules of octahedral symmetry, of the first three of these polarizabuities, the dipole quadrupole (A), dipole octopole (E) and dipole hexadecapole, only the second does not vanish [31, 32]. It may be specified by a single parameter E and the leading term in its contribution to thexz component of the mean-square polarizability (u^) of a pair of interacting molecules, I and 2, is <"iL> = ^ [("i^)2 - (^i)2]rr 0 + -. (5) where x and z are space-fixed axes. The bar indicates an average over the pair distribution function; <...> is an average over the orientations of 1 and 2 and of the intermolecular axis. The induced rotational tran- sitions whose intensity depends on (5) fol ow the selection rules A7 = 0 in one molecule and A/ = 1, 2. 3, 4, in the other. The next term in (5) varies as 153 Volume 118, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS J-ETTERS 19 July 198 r~1* and arises froin single transitions involving the dipole 2^-polepolarizability and double transitions involving E. It is expected to be about two orders of magnitude smaller than the r"10 term. Therefore (5) should provide a very good description of the rotational contribution to <o^z^- Theoretical spectra were gener- ated by multiplying (5) by the appropriate frequency and population factors [2] for each rotational line allowed by the selection rules. The rotational constant was taken to be 0.095 cm"1 - Because the rotational lines are so closely spaced, the width of the translational broadening function for each line is not critical and was estimated ic be 5 cm"1 - The absolute intensity depends on the magnitude of-fi" which was left as an adjustable parameter to be determined by fitting the calculated spectrum to experiment. An example of this spectrum is shown in fig. L Beyond 40 cm" * , the rotational spectrum is more intense than the purely translational component when the corrected DID ex- pression (2) is used for p(r). S. Comparison of theoretical and experimental spectra A total theoretical spectrum is shown compared with experiment in fig. 1- The theoretical spectrum was constructed with the corrected DID expression for (r), the estimated dimer spectrum, an induced rota- tional spectrum withf = 16.7 A5, and the McCoubrey and Singh potential. Better agreement is achieved in the range 40 70 cm^, than in 3 40 cm"1, pre- sumably because of the crude modelling of the con- tribution of the dimer component which has its largest effect in the latter region. Beyond 40 cm"1 > where the rotational spectrum is an important component, the shape of the experimental profile is very well re- produced. In table 1 are listed the values off obtained in this work, for the various potentials. The potential used is crucial to the estimate off; the value of ""10 differs by a factor of about two between computations willi the Powles or the MS potentials. The better Fit to the overall profile is obtained with the MS potential; in particular the curve calculated with the Powles potential is constantly below experiment from 0 to 25 cm"1. The choice of poladzabiltty model p(f) for the translational contribution also has sifinlficimt effect on the value deduced for '- If this component is modelled by tlic first-order DID contribution alone, Table 1 Valu es of E in A5 present work MS potential 16-7 4 Powles potential 24.6 4 Shelton and Tabisz. [3] <20 Pleich [33] a) <9 bond polaiizability model [2] 20 atom dipole interaction model [34] 9-456 a) Reported m r f. [34]. then the value of-E" obtained is lower by a factor of about two. Other choices for the dimer profile do nc significantly affect the magnitude off deduced. The zeroth moment of the total spectrum measur here is 1245 200 A9, in accord with the previous measurement of Shelton and Tabisz [3], 1166 A9. Calculation ofit-from Mo = 4w/PO-)2 r2 dr gives 1170 A^ with the MS potential and corrected DID model. The value obtained with the Powles po- tential is too low, 938 A9. 6. Summary The theoretical spectra represent the high-frequen wing of the spectra very well. Collision-induced rota- tional scattering is clearly present. The best fit is ob- tained when the corrected DID polarizability is used for the translational spectrum. Uncertainties in the analysis arise from the unavailability of an uncontesi Isotropie intennolecular potential. References [1] A.D. Buckingham and G.C. TabLue, Opt. Letter 1 (1977)220. [2] A.D. head.ce:title: Induced rotational Raman scattering and the dipole-octopole polarizability of SF6

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Physics, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada R3T 2N2

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The collision-induced depolarized light scattering spectrum of SF6 is measured in the frequency range 0–100 cm−1 at pressures of 11.6 to 19 atm at 295 K. Induced rotational Raman scattering is present but the magnitude of the dipole-octopole polarizability deduced depends markedly on the intermolecular potential.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: The virial coefficients of pure gases and mixtures
Raman spectroscopy of gases and liquids
Intermolecular spectroscopy and dynamical properties of dense systems
